data.title: Electron inserts itself into dnf.conf and breaks kernel update procedure on Fedora
data.body:
### Description

DNF is the prefered package manager for the Fedora GNU/Linux distribution. Atom's dependency, Electron, inserts a line into DNF's config file, aptly named `dnf.conf`. The inserted line alters the package manager's default behaviour with regard to kernel updates, such that: if a user (such as myself) upgrades to a new kernel, and the new kernel turns out to be unstable, there is no old kernel to fall back to. 

Default behaviour for Fedora's DNF package manager is to leave no more than two old kernels around as back ups, so that if a new version of the Linux kernel has issues, a user may easily boot to the previous version, or the one before that. Atom's dependency, Electron, alters this behaviour without any notice to, or consent from, the user. After the Atom editor has been installed on Fedora, updating the kernel removes any old versions, which, again, is not supposed to happen.

This is how a **normal** `dnf.conf` looks (no package is _ever_ supposed to make changes to it):

```
[main]
gpgcheck=1
installonly_limit=3
clean_requirements_on_remove=True
```

This is how my `dnf.conf` looked after Atom had mutilated it. **The last line, added by Atom, is crucial**, and affects dnf's procedure for installing kernel updates:

```
[main]
gpgcheck=1
installonly_limit=3
clean_requirements_on_remove=True
installonlypkgs=electron
```
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Install Atom on Fedora, using the official instructions provided here: https://github.com/atom/atom/

**Expected behavior:** 
I did not expect that a text editor would exhibit what I consider to be malicious behaviour: altering my package manager's configuration file without my knowledge or consent.

**Actual behavior:**
My package manager's config file **was** altered, which consequently meant that I had to spend time troubleshooting why my system wasn't behaving as expected. I also had to do this with a broken kernel, which meant doing something as simple as Alt+Tab took about ten seconds. Overall, not a pleasant experience, and not the way I would've liked to have used the last half an hour.

Thankfully, Fedora is meant for desktop use. As far as I am aware, neither CentOS nor RHEL use DNF to manage packages. Hopefully the damage this glaring oversight has caused will be limited in scope to the mere frustration of people using Fedora on their personal machines, such as myself.
### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.8.0
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

$ apm --version
apm  1.10.0
npm  1.3.6
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.11
git 2.5.5
```

data.title: to many code blocks
data.body:
### Description

When using the markdown render feature, I am having issues that cause the entire IDE to collapse into three skinny columns (that can still be interacted with.)  I tried recreate that issue, but so far have only found what follows.  I suspect it has to due with parsing several code blocks in a row.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. [First Step]
   ```
   a
   ```
       b
   ```
   c
   ```
2. [Second Step]

Try to render in editor.
1. [and so on...]

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

b to not be in code block

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

b is in code block
### Versions

1.8.0

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

data.title: Weird border from 620px left of the all panes.
data.body:
### Description

Unexpected border is showing ~620px left relative to every pane. There is no additional plugins or themes, also the screenshot is using the default ui and syntax coloring.

Note that there is no problem in the welcome section that the shortcut tips are showing off and the setting pane. The problem seems to be appearing in only project files like HTML.

![screenshot_23](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5216601/16542965/870b3a26-40c6-11e6-801d-b62e1a6eb96c.png)

Also in a smaller window;

![screenshot_24](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5216601/16542979/1c02a650-40c7-11e6-9334-b9944f31114b.png)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Atom

**Expected behavior:** For Border, not to show up.

**Actual behavior:** Unexpected border is showing 620px left relative to every pane.
### Versions

Windows 7, Atom v1.8.0 (Just downloaded and installed from atom.io)

data.title: Unsaved buffer lost during version upgrade
data.body:
### Description

Unsaved changes were lost during atom restart during an update.
No warning was displayed prompting the user to save the files.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Install atom 1.7.4
2. open a new tab and type some text in without saving to a file
3. open About Atom screen and trigger download updates
4. allow atom to restart

**Expected behavior:** 
when atom restarts, it should have the tab with the unsaved text or it should have warned  the user that there are unsaved changes and they will be lost so that the user can cancel the restart

**Actual behavior:** 
the tab containing the unsaved text was LOST
### Versions

Before update: Atom 1.7.4
After update: Atom 1.8.0 running on OSX El Capitan 10.11.5

data.title: Introduce TextEditor.prototype.update
data.body:
This will make it easier for views/components that use etch to use a `TextEditor` in their `render` method.

To make `scrollPastEnd` and `autoHeight` updatable, I segregated the knowledge of those two parameters into the `TextEditor` object, so that `TextEditorPresenter`, `TextEditorComponent` and `TextEditorElement` can just use it, applying the necessary changes upon initialization and when the `onDidChangeScrollPastEnd` and `onDidChangeAutoHeight` events trigger.

/cc: @nathansobo @atom/core

data.title: Split into lines not working
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [ ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [ ] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [ ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [ ] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [ ] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [ ] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

On OS X, Selection > Split into lines does not work
### Steps to Reproduce
1. [First Step]
   make a sentence with multiple words
2. [Second Step]
   Select the sentence
3. [and so on...]
   Click on the Selection menu, then split into lines.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
The lines should have split into multiple rows

data.title: Issue changing focus to a fullscreen Atom instance on OSX
data.body:
### Description

I have an Atom instance running in fullscreen mode and a terminal in fullscreen mode. If I use the `atom` command to open a file from the terminal the file opens but the window does not come into focus.

Some additional information is available in [the original discussion post](https://discuss.atom.io/t/issue-changing-focus-to-a-fullscreen-atom-instance-on-osx/30458), though the relevant information is reproduced here.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open an Atom workspace and put the window in fullscreen mode using the green button in the upper-left corner.
2. Open an terminal window and make it fullscreen as well.
3. Run the command `atom foo.txt:7` in the terminal (where `foo.txt` is an actual file).

**Expected behavior:** The file should open in the existing window and the Atom window should be in focus.

**Actual behavior:** The file is opening as expected, but the _desktop_ is in focus.
### Versions

Running on OS X 10.10.5.

output of `atom --version`:

```
Atom    : 1.9.0-beta0
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

output of `apm --version`:

```
apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.11
git 2.7.0
```

[Description of the bug or feature]

Launching atom via ssh (local 1G network), the window loads then atom crashes:

```
$ atom
$ /usr/local/bin/atom: line 115:  3464 Segmentation fault      (core dumped) nohup "$ATOM_PATH" --executed-from="$(pwd)" --pid=$$ "$@" > "$ATOM_HOME/nohup.out" 2>&1

Report Id:
Failed to get crash dump id.
Report Id:
Failed to get crash dump id.
Report Id:

```

I'm not sure why atom crashed, but I am proving the report so it can be addressed. The atom concept is good, but it has far to big a footprint to be usable to me.  1.1G for the atom source dir and 237M for the build - the entire KDE3 install is less:

```
$ du -hcs ../atom
1.1G    ../atom

$ du -hcs ../atom_build/
237M    ../atom_build/
237M    total

```

The last note I would add is you should provide an uninstall script that will clean the various pieces of atom that get scattered through the users $HOME directory in .cache, .config, .node-gyp, .pki, etc..

Keep up the good work and see if this issue can be fixed and perhaps atom can be paired down a bit to be more usable.

data.title: [BUG] Long single-line file crashes Atom every time.
data.body:
Some care needs to be taken by Atom when loading longs files or binary files, because crashing is not a good experience.

What's worse is that if the file is open in a project, if we restart Atom then load the project, Atom crashes again. So there's no way to open a project that crashed with that file open and the project is now useless. To solve the problem, the project has to be deleted and a new one created.

(Interesting to note that Vim and NeoVim don't crash when opening the same files, even with all my plugins installed, and remain responsive).

Related issues:
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/12049
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11992
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11894
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11831
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11110 (the number 11110 suits this issue well)
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/10917
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/9825
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8154
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/7583
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/7396

Guys, I think this is a serious issue and it should possibly have the highest priority over all other issues (seriously!). People don't like clicking on project-find search results only to have a crash (because it's not possible to tell how long a file is in those search results, for example, but it shouldn't even matter).
